item.title: Cori Bargmann
item.description: Margaret compared pairs of closely related species where one species is male/female and one is male/hermaphrodite. She found that females are highly motivated to mate. They chemotax to males, and cooperate with males during mating. They get less cooperative after they‚Äôve been mated, though. Hermaphrodites are unmotivated and uncooperative. But why? Two reasons ‚Äî they‚Äôve lost a specific olfactory response, and their own sperm makes them think they‚Äôre ‚Äúmated‚Äù.

item.title: Cori Bargmann
item.description: Lots of cool things Margaret learned from making/studying different conditions and mutants: hermaphrodites become cooperative in mating once they run out of sperm, or if they never make sperm; males and females use the same neurons to chemotax to the opposite sex. And another hermaphrodite species becomes even more female-like in the response to males when sperm-depleted. Their nervous systems are simple, but these latent and flexible behaviors teach us not to underestimate our model organisms.

item.title: Nicole Rust
item.description:
@thetransmitter
I‚Äôd like to give a shout out to Adrienne Fairhall (U Washington) and Pam Reinagel (UCSD).A few decades ago when I was in graduate school, I noticed that computationally inclined neuroscience labs were a bit like superhero troupes - always many guys and one girl. I (along with many others) watched carefully how Adrienne and Pam (a handful of years ahead) navigated that space, cheering them on from afar as they landed faculty positions, started families, and made their way through promotions. They were the existence proof for me and many others that even if we are the only girl in the room, we can do this too.

item.title: Clare
item.description: Last one for #SuperbOwl Sunday. Owls (and other Arctic Predators, avian and mammal) use rises and hummocks to scan for prey, using the same spots year after year. Their waste and remains of prey fertilize the spot and the plants grow taller there than the surrounding tundra. Here a juvenile Snowy peers at me from such a spot. #Nunavut #Arctic #WildlifePhotography #Birding

item.title: Dave Tang
item.description: There's this course called the Missing Semester (https://missing.csail.mit.edu/) that teaches you the practical stuff like using the CLI, shell scripting, Git, Vim, etc. It was created for CS students who apparently don't learn these things in class. But as a biochemistry/microbiology major turned bioinformatician, I need the CS course instead!
